Children have varied experiences with fairy tales. Classic fairy tales such as

are told differently in different cultures. And of course, every culture has its own traditional stories! Invite children to describe and even retell the tales they name, as best as they can. Encourage them to act out or draw their favorite scenes in centers.
Share the Mind Builder: Take Another Perspective

Everyone has different thoughts and different feelings. Sometimes, someone might feel and think differently than we do about the same thing. When we try to understand other people’s feelings, we take a different perspective. Understanding how other people feel helps us be a better friend and a better person!

Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about the characters’ feelings in the story.

Understanding that other people have different feelings and perspectives helps children see how their actions can affect others. Remind children that even if two people disagree, both perspectives can be valid. Remember, too, that perspective can affect relative size: A shirt that is too small on you may be too big for someone else. (Read et.al, 1980)
Review patterns. Choose two colors of Connecting Cubes, and model creating an ABAB pattern. Encourage children to guess what color the next cube will be.
Place hexagon and triangle Pattern Blocks in a bag. Have each child take a block. Ask children to stand in a pattern of large/small/large/small. Repeat using other patterns.

As we read today, think about this question:
What do the bears do when they come home?
As you read, point out this pattern: sizes are always listed in order from largest to smallest.

Does Goldilocks try the largest or the smallest bowl first? Which bowl does she try last?
Goldilocks always tries the largest thing first, then the middle-sized thing, then the smallest! What bed do you think she will try last?
Which bear checks his bowl first? Which bear checks his bowl last? What do you think the bears are thinking as they check their bowls?
Does the largest or the smallest bear check his chair first? I think the pattern of largest to smallest is here, too! Which bear do you think will check his chair last?
How do you think the baby bear feels when he sees that Goldilocks broke his chair?
The bears are going upstairs to check their beds. Which bear will check his bed first? Which bear will check his bed last?
Did you listen and remember as we read today? What do the bears do when they come home?
Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their answers.
Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about the order of bowls, chairs, and beds Goldilocks tries.

Put on a play! Invite five children to play the roles of Caterpillar, Rabbit, Leopard, Rhinoceros, and Frog. As you reread the story, encourage each child to make themselves seem as small or large as their character, and act out their actions. Repeat until all children have had a turn to act!
Provide a writing prompt about stories that have talking animals and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

Children compare size all the time, often without knowing it—they discuss portions of food, compare the sizes of toys, and measure their heights against their friends’. It is important to help children develop a conscious awareness of measurement with formal words (

Preschoolers may know that a small container holds less than a large one. It will take time for them to understand that containers that are tall and thin may hold the same amount as containers that are short and wide. Encourage children to use containers of many different sizes and shapes as they play so they can explore conservation.
